text: Tested on WinXP, Python 2.6 after installing pywin32 (pywin32-214.win32-py2.6.exe in my case):

code:
import win32api, win32con
def click(x,y):
    win32api.SetCursorPos((x,y))
    win32api.mouse_event(win32con.MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTDOWN,x,y,0,0)
    win32api.mouse_event(win32con.MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTUP,x,y,0,0)
click(10,10)

text: You can use win32api or ctypes to call win32 api call, to control mouse or any gui.
A fun sample here to control mouse ;) using win32api

code:
import win32api
import time
import math

for i in range(500):
    x = 500+math.sin(math.pi*i/100)*500
    y = 500+math.cos(i)*100
    win32api.SetCursorPos((x,y))
    time.sleep(.01)

import ctypes

# see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms646260(VS.85).aspx for details
ctypes.windll.user32.SetCursorPos(100, 20)
ctypes.windll.user32.mouse_event(2, 0, 0, 0,0) # left down
ctypes.windll.user32.mouse_event(4, 0, 0, 0,0) # left up
